review_title: Great company with great educational benefits
pros: fun place to work, great team, making a difference type of environment
cons: not many areas of growth opportunity

review_title: Sullivan University is a Terrible Place to Work
pros: Fair warning, this is a long review. If you are looking into working at Sullivan, I would encourage you to read all of it. I want to be exhaustive in my experience working here, so I can warn the next person. There is nothing I can say about the pros after evaluating my total experience working at Sullivan University. Thus, it is going to be one giant Cons of working at Sullivan. Do not work here. Sullivan University is a For-Profit, private university. All the institution cares about is bringing in money by any means necessary. Don't be tempted by the slightly higher than average industry pay that Sullivan offers. The education at Sullivan University is terrible. My particular area of work was admissions in their Allied Health programs, particularly nursing. Nursing students at Sullivan University that actually get through the nursing program (many don't), as of 2022, ONLY 43.3% of nursing students pass the NCLEX which is required for employment in nursing. This information can be found on the Kentucky Board of Nursing: Prelicensure Program of Nursing Benchmarks. This means that 56.7% of Sullivan University nursing students take on tens of thousands of dollars of student loan debt and won't be able to go into nursing. As an Admissions Advisor, we are instructed by management to heavily push student loans onto students, even if it means adding a crushing burden of debt onto the students, all for the sake of "hitting the numbers". Not to mention that their student retention rate is terrible. We are told to factor students dropping out of the program into our enrollment goals. Students that drop out still have to pay the loans they took out, and the way Sullivan prepares their financial package, they have to pay for 3 semesters/quarters at a time. Meaning that if the student drops out after the first semester/quarter, they will still have to pay for the second and third. In the eyes of the admissions office at Sullivan, you are not a student, you are a lead. You are a means to acquire money, that is it. They prey particularly on the underprivilege "leads" and use predatory techniques to rope you into attending Sullivan. During the introductory admissions training, I was instructed to always control of the conversation and not let the "lead" ask questions. To solidify Sullivan University's commitment to exploiting their "leads", I was reprimanded for saying at the end of a call, "Do you have any other questions before I let you go?". This is predatory, plain and simple.
cons: I am now going to move on to my personal experience working here. To give a little background, I have prior experience in higher education admissions. I worked for an admissions office that was wildly successful before working at Sullivan. Before starting, I read the other plethora of negative reviews here on Glassdoor but merely thought that the reviews were made by people who slacked off or didn't know how an admissions office works. I was wrong. As an Admissions Advisor, you have weekly accountability meetings to discuss your progress and enrollment numbers. During my meetings I was told I was doing a phenomenal job and that I picked the job up much quicker than most (which makes sense with my prior experience). Then without warning, was called into the office and fired without reason. You will have no job security if you work here. Managment is playing with students and employee's lives, all in the name of making more money for Sullivan. I declined a promotion at my previous institution to come work at Sullivan. If you work at Sullivan, you are just a number, nothing more. Don't expect to keep a job here if you don't plan on using their predatory practices to recruit underprivilege students. Naturally, the enrollment goals are unrealistic (the following numbers were told to me by my supervisor). Sullivan University's enrollment was at an all-time low prior to (not because of) COVID of approximately 1900 and they want to double that number to over 4000 within the next couple years (currently at low 2000s) without the willingness to improve the education. Additionally, comments were made about my physical appearance by a former dean that made me feel deeply uncomfortable. To give a little context, I am a young male, and the former dean is a much older female. On multiple occasions, she made remarks about my appearance that made me very shocked, uncomfortable and unwanted. If the roles were reversed (an older, male superior making comments about a younger, female worker) it would be deemed highly inappropriate.

pros: Had some nice people to work with.
cons: Management was not very nice.

pros: -Good place to work if you like processes being followed (this may have changed since 2020) -responsive HR team -Education benefits
cons: -Low pay -expensive, minimal health benefits -unrealistic and unreasonable goals for Admissions team

pros: Not many pros to share aside from the occasional satisfaction of helping a truly dedicated student complete their enrollment.
cons: Questionable sales practices bordering on unscrupulous. The university preys on hopeless students offering their proprietary education as salvation. These students incur immense debt pursuing degrees that aren't worth the paper they're written on.

pros: Low Work Load Enjoyable Coworkers Many work parties 90% off tuition for full time employees
cons: -Grossly low pay, I have a Bachelors my job required a bachelors, and I only make $16 an hour -Was promised WFH days and yet the company took them away for the whole department -Not a lot of ways to actually help the students. The school constantly talks about how we need to increase enrollment and retention, but does not give us any way on how to actually do that. Calling the students constantly to ask them to send us documents and payments only frustrates and stresses them out. The only helpful service we offer students is 7 free sessions with a school counselor. -Admissions is a sales based role where they try their hardest to get students to enroll and do that by misleading students that we offer services that we don't actually offer. Students have been mislead into thinking that the career services department helps current students, it only helps graduates. Students have been mislead that certain credits will transfer when they will not. I understand why Admissions does this, their job is threatened if they do not meet numbers. -No forgiveness for students. I've often had to harass students to get me transcripts that are ridiculous to request. Several students will have college degrees but will be allowed to attend one Quarter just to be told that they can't come back until they have their High School Diploma. Why does a student need to give us their HS if they have college? Some students have come from war torn, poor countries and can not provide a high school transcript. One student has even explained that their "former high school is rubble". -I've often seen coworkers and middle management bend over backwards and jump through hoops to help a student, but often be shot down because of dated policies from the big wigs. -As crazy as it sounds, I feel bad for middle management, an insane amount of unrealistic expectations is pushed onto their shoulders and plate, so I don't take it personally when that is trickled down. -Inconsistent workload. The break weeks will be insanely busy but the rest of the quarter is insanely slow. I'll walk around looking for anything to do. I can finish my days work in about 30minutes to an hour depending. It sounds great on paper, but doing nothing for 7 hours is torture. -Health Insurance is trash -Was promised in interview that there a lot of opportunities for upward advancement, yet after a year I haven't seen any.

pros: Private Institute Good salaries for health care
cons: For profit institution No 401K matching

pros: Flexible and supportive staff. They provide growth opportunities.
cons: classes are crowded. 65 student per class is typical.

pros: Nice co-workers, offered a couple of days working at home/week
cons: No training, very low pay, low employee morale

job_title: Financial Planning Coordinator in Louisville, KY
pros: Good benefits, decent pay, small company
cons: Little to no guidance or leadership, thrown to the wind, very little work to actually be done. From day one I was constantly asking for work to do or walking around asking every employee in my department if I could help with anything and was consistently left with nothing to do but was told it was okay to spend my abundance of spare time on my phone or work computer. Management told me to observe other workers’ appointments (which I did). I was given a list of people to call ONE time and had it done within 20 minutes and that was the last task I was given, a week ago. When I was fired, I was told that it was due to me not being a good fit and was given no other information, even when I asked. I was told that I could contact HR but that they would tell me the same thing. This is my first time being let go and I have worked for state departments. I now see that Sullivan University has less than a four star rating here on glass door, and have made a mental note to check here before leaving long term employment for a “better opportunity.”

pros: Close to home. Hour long lunches. Some employees were very friendly. The Culinary Arts department is fantastic!
cons: Mean girls galore. If you weren't part of the "popular club" your life was awful. Management was the worst. Goals were unrealistic and unattainable for the cost of tuition. If management didn't like you they made it known and actively tried to get your fired or for you to quit on your own. Awful place.

review_title: Very little ups, plenty of downs
pros: The pay was decent for "entry level" employment and training was helpful. They also paid for travel.
cons: Horrible mentality of bosses and coworkers. Admissions reps were looked at as inside sales associates and were meant to pump up numbers, even if it meant students would not be there for the completion of their degree.

review_title: Not Worth What They Will Pay You
pros: I met a few awesome co-workers. Getting to work with students was great and the connections I made with them is the only reason I stayed as long as I did.
cons: Management is terrible. They do not care about their employees or their students. Everyone in management only cares about themselves and their jobs. They will throw you under the bus in a heartbeat to save themselves. Very toxic environment. If you are not in the inner circle then you do not matter. If you try to voice concerns, you will be punished and written up later. Nothing you do will be good enough. You're either calling too many students and not scheduling enough appointments or you're scheduling too many appointments with students and not calling enough. The only thing that matters is numbers. They do not care if you are setting students up to fail. As long as you meet goal, that is the only thing that matters. Also, the majority of people have no clue about how higher education is. This company is ran as a business and not a college at all. If you have a passion for students, they will kill that. They pay more than most Admissions positions and I believe it is to get people to start working there and make them feel like they can't leave because they can't afford the pay cut. However, that paycheck is not worth the damage to your mental health this place will cause. The benefits are also terrible so really, you aren't making more than other similar positions because you are paying so much for benefits.

job_title: International Compliance Specialist in Louisville, KY
pros: Small university where everyone knows each other.
cons: Benefits are abysmal. Low vacation days/personal days/sick days. Only 24 hours of emergency leave. Low salaries.

pros: great schedule and paid time off
cons: low pay for Louisville area

job_title: Associate Director of Housing and Residence Life in Louisville, KY
pros: wonderful opportunities for advancement and growth. Housing is honestly the best department in my opinion :) But overall company is pretty amazing.
cons: Work life Balance issues. Hard to feel like a human when you are having to care for everyone else.

pros: Educational benefits after a year, but health insurance is so expensive and the toxic environment is so poor, it’s not worth staying and jeopardizing your mental health over.
cons: Frequent layoffs. Unethical hiring practices, toxic management and senior management. The university cares more about profit than the wellbeing of its employees. They also require a two weeks notice if you wish to resign yet they can terminate you immediately if you decide to be respectful and put in a notice. I’m sure the university had previously been an amazing place to work, but now it’s run by petty managers who talk bad about their employees behind their backs but smile when those same employees donate to their Heart Walk. And it’s sad to see those managers molding the minds of good employees. It’s all over an bad experience mixed with a couple of good coworkers too naive to see the toxic environment around them.

pros: Education benefits are great. Management and coworkers are very responsive. Had many positive interactions with faculty and students.
cons: Executive leadership generally not competent and goals for admissions team unreasonable. Benefits are horrible, insurance incredibly expensive. Lack of top-down transparency.

review_title: Pay is good but managers are terrible
pros: Money and the cafeteria. Yeah. That's it.
cons: Management (that's the biggest issue), predatorial tactics on kids with no real chance. favoritism toward women

review_title: Lies and More Lies.. Retention and Enrollment Valued More than Education.
pros: Coworkers were great and I enjoyed teaching
cons: Administration will lie to your face about job security to keep you from quitting. Merger and SACS accreditation changed everything. Many long term employees were stabbed in the back and lost jobs after years of employment and being promised they were safe. Students were accepted into programs where they had zero chance of success. Education is not the focus, money and retention are.

pros: Lots of experience in a short amount of time.
cons: They ask a lot from you.

pros: The pros of working at Sullivan University is the freedom you are allowed in regard to teaching.
cons: Terrible management and if you were a favorite, then you received preferential treatment.

pros: The university has a real family feel- I attribute this to being owned by the Sullivan family for over 50 years. There is a big emphasis on personal service, which you don't find at bigger state schools or other private sector schools. Many opportunities for professional development, including free Dale Carnegie training, and the ability to volunteer on many projects to help expand your skill set. In Admissions they do have a tier system to help employees promote from within and earn additional money. Of course, one of the biggest benefits is free education after one year of full-time service. The way I look at it, this is really additional income! Without it, you would have to take out tens of thousands of dollars in student loans to earn a Bachelors or Masters. There is regular coaching and feedback given to help support you in the pursuit of goals and to develop your skill set. Management is always doing stuff for employees, like bringing in free food, letting you work remotely or even a flexible schedule, and coming up with fun activities for employees to participate in. This keeps the work atmosphere fun in what can be a challenging position! The biggest reward is seeing the result of your hard work- students who are pursuing higher education, graduating, and changing their lives. There aren't too many professions where you can get that kind of satisfaction.
cons: You do have to work hard and make a lot of calls; if that's not your thing, then this probably isn't the right place for you. Sometimes they keep under performing employees around too long; this can be demotivating for those who are getting it done.

pros: Family atmosphere, coworkers, flexible schedule, fun events, and it’s enjoyable to work with students.
cons: Pay, benefits, little opportunity for growth

pros: Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck. Paycheck.
cons: Rather than foster a truly positive work atmosphere, senior management prefers to plant positive reviews on sites such as this so that prospective new hires won't know the truth. It is true that Sullivan was a "Best Place to Work in 2014" but it is also true that SU was the last employer to make the cut this year, narrowly snapping a nearly 30 year drought. Even with management making fake reviews (always days after a legitimate but negative review, obviously to counteract the ugly truth), SU still can't break 2 stars and a 40% approval rating. That alone speaks volumes.

pros: Remote work opportunities. Tuition waiver after one year of employment.
cons:
Any reviews on here with 5 starts with generic comments are intentionally planted by HR. This institution practices an aggressive for-profit recruiting model. There is absolutely nothing more important than hitting enrollment goals without regard to student quality. The role of an “admissions advisor” is completely misleading! People in admissions are sales representatives accountable to hit a specific number of enrollments every recruiting period. The entire department structure is flawed because their salespeople can’t get commissions or bonuses for hitting enrollment goals due to Department of Education restrictions. But their performance is evaluated based on hitting those enrollment goals. And, when those numbers are not on-point with management’s expectations, termination is eminent after ineffective sales coaching by management. 

Seasoned staff members in the department are institutionalized casualties of generations of futile and toxic management. Any talented hires have come and gone after realizing the cruel truth about the culture. People employed for many years at this institution feel stuck and have no aspirations for growth nor would have opportunities at other higher education institutions. Sullivan University has no strategic plan in place to serve students. They are only focused on enrollment numbers just like a business pushing product to the market. Without a doubt, this institution is a black hole for talent. If anyone is interested in working for Sullivan University, especially in the admissions department, should know what to expect and make the best out of their experience while they are employed and move on after getting what they need to advance in their careers. Other than that, this is not a long-term place of employment.

pros:
I’ve been with Sullivan for several years. This school truly does take an individual approach to the students. They are given individual attention at every level. I’ve mostly had good management experiences. There have been a few really bad managerial choices, but typically those people haven’t lasted long. I’ve read some of the other reviews, and I’m honestly shocked that some of our former faculty members felt they were preying on their students.  That’s very sad. The students that return to thank me for helping them find a school that works for them certainly don’t feel that way. Recent staff cuts due to a merger of the three separate Sullivan schools have led to a lot of sour grapes. Read the recent reviews with a grain of salt. 
The management encourages fresh ideas, and every person is taught to be 100% transparent and honest  in all interactions with students. 
The management after encourages fresh ideas....
cons: But is often very slow to implement new ideas. There is also very much of a good Old boy network here where promotions are often based on who you’re buddies with rather than the right fit for the job. This has led to some monumental fails in leadership over the years.

review_title: Toxic Environment from Leadership and Terrible Benefits
pros: Higher base pay than other positions (but we'll get more in-depth with this in a minute.)
cons:
1. The "benefits" that are overpriced and don't really cover anything, which eats up a lot of your pay

2. The joke of an EAP they offer through Wayne Corp. Everyone I talked to who used it said that they got no benefit from it.

3. The Chancellor openly discusses his political beliefs during meetings, which is unprofessional and creates an uncomfortable working environment. One of the most notable times when I was there was when he said that the school was no longer seeking non-profit status because Trump won the election, and how great that was because (exact words), "as bad as Obama was for our business, Hillary would have been a thousand times worse."

4. The amount of bent truths and lies told to current and prospective students is appalling and should be illegal, in my opinion. Students are roped into the culinary program with promises of being an executive chef or some other high-level culinary professional making well over $50K a year. This doesn't happen 99% of the time, and they are stuck as a line cook making $13 an hour with over $80K in debt.

pros: Sullivan has definitely made some changes in the past year that make working here a pleasure. Anyone who wants to work can find a happy home here. Anyone that wants to be paid to slack off may not be as happy. Overtime policies have changed to be 1.5x pay for overtime. Benefits are good. Opportunities for advancement are presented to those who demonstrate an ability to do their job well. Lots of training is provided and the culture provides a lot of little perks and a lot of fun to break up the day.
cons: Some people may have a hard time accepting that they can't just show up 9-5 every day and never have to work late, work overtime, or work a weekend activity. These people probably don't belong in a work environment that requires more than the bare minimum. It can be frustrating to deal with potential students who are flakey, but that comes with the territory.

pros:
Work freedom - I and the other members of my section/department are allowed to make decisions concerning what we do and how we do it, then are generally backed up by management.

Coworkers - Great people, very smart. I have learned a lot.

Benefits - Educational benefits are top-notch. Personally, I do not participate in any of the benefits except PTO, but they are about average.

Work-life balance - I know there a lot of positions in which this is a problem, but it is great for mine. I work 40 hours a week, often on a flexible schedule, but I usually get to determine that flexibility. Haven't had to work OT in the 5 years here.

I have worked in many places. This one has its faults, but is not so bad.
cons:
My pay is somewhat lower than comparable positions in other schools and industries.

Long term planning and project management are poor. The university often tries to tackle too many projects at a time, only to have to drop one or more. We are currently working a major project for which we have seen no comprehensive plan from management.

pros: Committed and dedicated faculty. Nice perks with the culinary programs in regard to events and discounts at the Bakery and Winston's restaurant. Usually a fun working environment with many good employees. Helping others and making a positive difference in one's life.
cons: High level of stress to achieve numbers with top leadership disconnected. Too many inexperienced middle managers with more regard for their title and control rather than the focus on coaching employees and helping students. Good old boys club in executive office with unethical VP destroying organization. Most of the good employees have sadly left due to the tyrannical rule of the one with the Napoleon complex. I could no longer be associated with an organization that so blindly allowed and promoted bullying in the workplace. HR definitely not an employee advocate, beware.

review_title: Good pay and benefits, but needs to get with the times!
pros: Good benefits (although they are expensive) but the employee tuition benefit is spectacular! The school works hard to ensure they live up to their mission and vision, which increases services to students. Good advancement opportunities.
cons: Work/life balance is horrible, depending on the position.  There is inequality between service departments which can increase tension, frustration, and resentment between departments- who have to deal with each other daily.  There is good intent to train staff, but many of the training programs are outdated, insufficient, or simply non-existent.

pros: There are some great people working there.
cons: To say the benefits package is competitive is a complete lie. They do not even match 401k. The “GLI Best Place to Work” is fake - none of the employees have ever even seen the survey that allegedly wins us the “Best Place to Work” title. They care way more about numbers and profit than students or best practices. All of Senior Leadership make six figures - many of which only have a Bachelors degree, including the president of the school - but entry level employees are required to have a Master’s to make even $50k. They resist change and improvements at every turn and refuse to keep up with competitors, but then blame staff for low enrollment. It’s great that they lowered tuition, but then they slashed scholarship opportunities. It’s an extremely toxic environment where everyone is competing with one another. There is an egregious lack of respect for employees’ personal time and work/life balance.

review_title: A very well run University that exceeds all of the SACS and ACICS accreditation standards.
job_title: Director of Admissions in Lexington-Fayette, KY
pros: Probably the best value proposition for a private university in the state of Kentucky. Quality education at a reasonable cost. The Chancellor and all of management care 1000 more times about their students than the tuition dollars. That is the key to Sullivan's success.
cons: When will the other shoe drop. I'm surprised that there has been no class action law suite filed from current and former Admissions Officers regarding the 1/2 of the hourly rate for overtime compensation. In addition to that the Associate Directors of Admissions, who truly don't manage anybody were paid no overtime of any kind for working 60 hour weeks to make their extraordinarily high start plans.

job_title: Former Faculty Member in Louisville, KY
pros: Adequate technology in classrooms. Dedicated faculty, although I feel sorry for them.
cons:
You are treated more like an expendable used car salesman working on commission, than an educator. 
Judging from the graduation speakers they often invite, it's clear that some of the top brass are angry Tea Party members.
As an educator in this system, you WILL be asked to pass students who shouldn't be passed, and to tweak exam results to buffer grades, in order to keep students and their money in the program. 
Administrators are more invested in building a facade of academic fortitude, than they are in improving outcomes.
If you have no ethics, or can easily turn a blind eye to others' utter lack of ethics, then this is the place for you.

pros: You can get your masters for free if you can last 12 months. This is for profit education. The building is decent. The location of the campus is in a decent part of town.
cons: This is for profit school. Admissions is 100% sales. If you don't meet your goal you will be harassed by management. You will never see management work as hard the people under them. People gossip a lot and it's very clique oriented. I Have been with the school for years and witnessed some amazing talent come through however, this school never deserved them.

review_title: For Profit Admissions At Its Finest
pros: Education benefit, great team members, growth opportunities.
cons: Terrible hours, management is awful, corporate run, no care for students, all a numbers game, only care about profit, poor campus level leadership.

review_title: I was micromanaged, treated unfairly - no room for creativity
pros: Helping students get enrolled in school....feeling like you are helping them succeed.  Most instructors (and academic department heads) really care about the students
cons: Very unfair working environment.  What is acceptable for one person is not acceptable for another.  You are micro managed, worked long hours -- many many Saturdays -- often with short notice.  Autocratic management.   Do not try to be creative when working there, they want robots that will say exactly what they tell them to say, no thinking outside the box or doing things differently.

review_title: Thank god I din't work here anymore
pros: Many nice co-workers, decent insurance, free tuition
cons: Most of the deans are morons who got their degrees from Sullivan or some other third world college.  The Sullivan family are oddballs who are so removed from normal people, they just don't get it.  HR is just a bunch of mean, close-minded gossipers, upper management is just a bunch of old dudes who couldn't get a job at a real school.  I was always embarassed to say I worked at Sullivan because everyone in the city knows the place is a joke.

pros: Sullivan University is a great place to work. I work with some amazing people whose mission matches mine -- we're helping people change lives for the better. Overall benefits are great, senior leadership listens and is open to new ideas. The company is determined and willing to invest in employee development. I am very excited about the future of this company!
cons: As many companies out there, Sullivan University had many changes in leadership but all good. It will take some time to reboot the system and to clean up the "negative" mindset caused by former employees who did not care about the company and who are luckily no longer work here.

review_title: Not the best place to work, but not the worst.
pros: Great co-workers. Nice facilities and students for the most part care about their education. Not much else to say, just trying to meet the minimum.
cons: Pay and benefits are awful! Upper admin is not much better. The profits are not being invested back into the facilities or students as far as I can tell.

review_title: The faculty at Sullivan is not treated as a valuable business asset.
job_title: Marketing Department Chair in Louisville, KY
pros: The only two benefits of teaching at Sullivan University are the relative degree of autonomy, and a generally flexible schedule.
cons: The faculty at Sullivan are treated like fast-food workers, with an emphasis on serving as many customers in a timely fashion as possible. They are seen as infinately replaceable, and are not expected to truly teach, but simply provide customer service. They aggressively recruit from populations not ready for college level work, and provide poor systems for learning and graduation, fully expecting a significant number of students to fail and eventually default on their student loans.

pros: Management is excellent at pretending everything is alright. The fresh paint on the walls every summer makes me happy. Plenty of opportunity to be fed and have information regurgitated that is not factual all in the name of "caring".
cons: The company focuses solely on profit and does not care who they have to exploit to get there. It is sad that many students do not feel that their best interest is whole heartedly considered. Poor branding. Poor leadership. Confrontation between departments. Constant changes that are impossible to keep track of. Conflicting policies. Benefits are not family friendly.

pros: Co-workers, eating the food from the Culinary department...that's really about all.
cons: Management, Hours, Pay, Benefits, other departments employees, negative environment. Things will be good for the first 6 months and then you'll realize how badly you messed up accepting that job.

review_title: Surreal:  The ability to ignore reality and pretend daily that there are consistent successful outcomes is quite amazing
job_title: Senior Associate Director in Louisville, KY
pros: As long as you receive a nod from 'elite group of senior leadership' your inability to perform means nothing.  Moreover, you are 'safe' and will not be held accountable for continued failure.
cons: The biggest 'con' is the trickle down effect of poor leadership to the most important part of the organization:  the students (consumers).  Morally, ethically, and legally there are grave injustices that occur daily.

review_title: Um, its' a nice stop.. but not a career
pros: Coworkers... are fantastic!   The pay is "so so" and the benefits are pretty good.
cons: Corporate - they have 100% lost what's going on outside of SUS.  The tuition rates are higher than nearly every university in the state and you don't get nearly the same experience.  They really need to look in the mirror and analyze who they are...

pros: Nice atmosphere in my department. Good pay. Fun job. Free education for self and family members. Stable company with a future.
cons: Managers are slave drivers. 12 hour days 6 days a week. An atmosphere of fear in other departments seeps into our own. Constant reorganization. Major issues are ignored rather than addressed.

pros: Clean environment, good computer/IT systems all over.  Pretty much left alone in teaching a class.  The place is not a diploma mill and does no pressure faculty to pass all students.
cons: They ant facuty to feel loyal to the school, and although they give lip service to faculty appreciation, the loyalty goes only one way.  Their bottom line is making money, although they do put the profits back into the institution.

pros: The team you work with is great. They hire people that fit well on the team except at the management level.
cons: Stop the lying, hire new management from the top down. The AOs are not the problem. They work very hard with very little care from the management. If someone is to be let go it is the AO. Did I mention stop the lying and start being honest. People want to hear the truth not hypothetical farce situations created in managements mind

pros:
Administration pretty much leaves you alone, re:classroom activities.  Facilities
 are kept clean and in tip-top condition; seems like the walls are painted between every quarter.
cons: Students are the "paying customers", and some of he newer administrators believe "the customer is always right."  Emphasis on student retention sometimes leads to breaches of academic freedom, when profs get pressured to keep the customer happy.

review_title: Never work here, Never go to school here, Never send your children here
pros: Free education while employeed for self, children, and spouse.
cons: Favoritism, long hours, unethical, greedy, last minute notice of weekend hours, unorganized, lack of accountability, terrible reviews, no follow up, students allowed to start class up to two weeks late when they have no proven ability to successfully complete these classes, set up to fail.

job_title: Career Services Specialist in Louisville, KY
pros: Great work environment and mission. Coworkers are very welcoming and (for the most part) enjoy their job. Amazing mission with excellent opportunities for professional growth.
cons: Some of the leadership is stagnant with managers/supervisors often staying in the same position for 15+ years. While this speaks wonders for tenure, it prevents creativity and market agility.

pros: Some of the folks at Sullivan are good people. The management system in place ruins this though because they do not care about the student anymore in the corporate office and the few folks that care are treated like garbage, pretty sad really.
cons: There were many good people over the years that  gave tremendously not to mention the sacrifices made only to watch over the past decade the most management decision debacle in the history of Sullivan University.

review_title: Understands the need for work life balance of its employees.
pros: Family atmosphere with supportive and friendly co-workers and supervisors.  The company really makes an effort to show employees they are valued.  Free tuition for employees and dependents!  Nothing says family-friendly like free college education for my kids!
cons: Lots of long-term employees, although a good thing, means there is not always a promotional opportunity for those who are ready. Many have left and come back, though, which just says how great of a place it is.

pros: Boss allowed us to have a lot of fun within our department
cons:
Too much drama and bitterness between departments
Director of campus is out to make sure the admissions department does not succeed
Impossible to succeed considering the reputation of the school, the cost of the school, and the lack of updated programs of study
Revolving door of new hires
Training is inadequate
Major lack of job security

review_title: Sullivan University: Where morale can't get any Lowe-r
pros: Tuition Benefits, the Sullivan Bakery is nice.
cons: Poor leadership, Human Resources is non-exsistant, micro-managing, departments at war with each other, student's treated like customers at a fast food restaurant, Employees reminded that they are expendable, favoritism, discrimination, Lack of moral compass of upper management.

pros: I really can't think of much to say that is positive.
cons: Culture of this company is terrible. They are in denial that their reputation exceeds itself , so they expect you to sell this company to poor students who are signing away thousands of dollars in student loans... Knowing they can't get gainful employment.

pros: As a faculty member, I'd say the best experience of working at Sullivan was getting to know the students and trying to make their time their somewhat positive.
cons:
The cons were going to work on a daily basis under the pretense of a teacher/student environment.  While I accepted the position with every intention of this being the chase, I soon found out that it was nothing more than smoke & mirrors. Many of the students were questionable college material and yet, as instructors, we were urged to find ways to help them pass their classes so their college tuition could continue. The college experience that I was teaching resembled nothing of the one that I had known. 
The worst was yet to come. Upon leaving this company, I began my own job search. I have never had so many doors shut in my face at the mention of my employment at Sullivan University. I can't imagine what graduates from this school have had to endure, all with insurmountable debt.  To add salt to the wound, when I run into any of my former students now, there seems to be an underlying coldness that I feel is because they think I was in on the scam. This is the worst part of the whole horrible experience.
If you are considering accepting a faculty position at Sullivan, you really should reconsider.  The reviews on here that are real and truthful should not be ignored. Do yourself a favor and take a pass.

pros: Great Benefits. It's a pleasure assisting the students in achieving their goals
cons: Too many people doing their own thing without advice from owner. A lot of confusion within the departments as well as advice that is relayed to the students. No on is on the same page.

pros: Good training and decent benefits.
cons: Tough to justify their expensive educational benefits if students don't need to use those benefits.  Egos among upper management are horrendous.  Tt is an "ol' boy" network.  Its a shame that many do not "walk their talk."  Owner is too loyal (to his detriment) to many in management if they've been there a long time.

pros:
- Easy commute. Centrally located. Entrance is right next to 264.
- Relaxed work environment.
- Full-time employees can receive an Associate's, Bachelor's, or Master's degree essentially free of charge.
- Recently became SACS accredited.
- The area surrounding campus is great for light exercise.
- Internet isn't restricted so you can apply for other jobs during breaks from work.
- Staff discount at book store and bakery, which is useful because goods there tend to be very overpriced.  (However, according to a recent memo from the CEO you can't even get free water from the Cafe's soda fountain even if you have your own cup without putting yourself at risk of write-up or termination.)
cons:
- High turnover in every department. In the past two months, Sullivan has lost two department directors, two associate directors, and numerous subordinates. Corporate isn't replacing many of the vacancies, which sets the stage for more burnout among the few remaining good workers.
- Draconian compensation plans. High-handed HR policy. Many former and current staff have legitimate back pay issues.
- Uncertain future.  Enrollment is down system-wide, hence the multiple January 2013 layoffs.  Also the system is constantly at odds with local, state, and federal levels of government, so it attracts political pressure to add to the already existing economic strain.
- Sloppy management. Performance reviews aren't conducted regularly. Policies often change from week to week. Schedules aren't usually reliable. Employees arrive late, leave early, and take long lunches on the clock without consequence.
- Blatant favoritism.  One group is told a lie to justify an injustice, then management contradicts itself to justify preferential treatment of another group months later.
- Almost as many bosses as there are subordinates. (How can you truly be a "director" when you only "direct" 1-3 people at any given time? Who's the boss?)
- Health insurance premiums are too high relative to the plans' benefits. Most healthy, single people are better off with individual insurance.
- HR serves the corporate interest exclusively. That arm of the university is not impartial. The defensive attitude that it defaults to is unfair to employees.
- No child care even though Sullivan trains child care providers.
- You will be exposed to toxic chemicals in poorly ventilated work areas for entire work days many times a year because Corporate chooses not to do work of this nature on Sundays when campus is empty. This is especially a problem if you are pregnant or nursing as many of our staff have been.

review_title: Things are going from bad to worse
pros:
-Decent starting salary (if you don't consider the absolutely insane "half-time" overtime [fun fact: literally the more hours you work, the less you make], or the fact that you are pretty underpaid for the amount of stress you encounter daily)

-My co-workers were the best part of the job -- everyone in my admissions department was fantastic, but unfortunately that can't be said for the entire campus or system.
cons:
I worked in admissions at the Spencerian campus in Lexington. Cons? Not sure even where to begin with that one. 

For starters, I was lied to in my interview about everything from job duties to turnover rates (found out two days into the job that most people last there under six months, after being told in the interview that there was very little job turnover, and if so, it was because people were promoted - LOL nope).

I was also told that, although there was -some- recruitment involved, that most of my job would involve meeting with prospective students who'd applied into the school, to advise them on what programs would be a good fit for them. Again, LOL nope. On the first day of "training" (in quotations because it was 2 or 3 days of half-assed tutorials about stuff that barely related to the job) we were informed that we would be expected to make 100+ outbound calls per day, and that many times these calls were almost like cold-calling (inquiries were bought from a company who used less than reputable means to get them - many people thought they were applying for a job, not giving us their info).

We were constantly pressured to get more applications, regardless of whether it was in the best interest of the student. Well, I take that back - they would "say" that we should only offer applications to "qualified applicants" who were a good fit, then if we became picky with who we chose, we were berated for not getting more of our interviews to apply. There were constant threats of losing our jobs if we did not get more applications.

I felt very uncomfortable admitting people to college who were barely qualified to do it (even though the school itself is a joke - but that's another story), especially because the programs were so outrageously expensive ($50,000 for an associates degree?!) and the salary outlooks for those programs often maxed out at $13/hr. 

I believe the Sullivan University System preys on the low-income and disadvantaged, taking their money and happily putting them into massive debt they will never get out of, without any concerns for the long-term futures of these students. 

I ultimately quit because I refuse to compromise my integrity, and the more I learned about my job and about the SUS, the more I realized that was what I was expected to do every day.

pros: Employee tuition program is a great benefit, although you must last for at least one year to enroll and then another 18 months (at full-time status) to complete your graduate degree.  Program options are limited, but I am thankful for the opportunity to continue my education and advance my career in higher education.
cons: The cost of benefits is simply outrageous and the coverage is catastrophic health insurance.  They offered only a few options of plans and I knew of at least two full-time professional employees that opted out of the coverage simply because they could not afford the cost.

pros:
Educational benefits after 1 year.
There are some really great departments to work for.
cons: Leadership, when it exists, is reactionary and ill-informed. Many changes happen without a great deal of thought. We have lost some good people and promoted several who were useless. There is little to no communication.

pros: The students were the only pros. Most were a joy to teach and to get to know. I had creative freedom in the classroom for the most part.
cons: The administration. What a joke. It was unbelievable to attend their faculty "retreats" and/or training in-service days. Even the graduation ceremony was such a farce, where the administrators and those who kissed up to them sat around telling each other how great their "institution" was. These people are nuts!

pros: The people at Sullivan are top notch.  The hiring process was smooth and the current staff make you feel welcome.
cons: There are not enough students to work full time.  The students are not as motivated as I would like them to be but the University has good policies.

review_title: Sullivan is a great place to work.
pros: Working at Sullivan has given me the opportunities for professional and personal growth while  working in a positive team environment where individuals are treated with respect and encouraged to succeed. Sullivan's corporate environment in general, and Global e-Learning in particular, is focused on providing our students with the best customer service available.
cons: Growth is dependent on the career track you're in.

pros: The students.  This was the only reason for coming into the job.
cons: There are Deans and other people who did not care about the students.  It was about the all mighty dollars.  Upper management

pros:
Benefits (tuition)
Average pay, 
Willing to provide training
Co-workers are hard working
Instructors are friendly and knowledgeble
cons:
Management doesn't seem like they care about department morale.
A lot of programs added to process and it is bogging down employees.

job_title: Associate Director of Admissions in Louisville, KY
pros: Full tuition waiver after one year of employment. Compensation according to industry standard.
cons: Very political environment. No opportunity for advancement unless you are friends with the leadership. Talent is wasted and not valued at all. Promotions are not based on merit and extremely limited.

pros: Decent benefits, nice people at the bottom.
cons: Unethical leadership, petty rivalries, management and sales staff lie to people to get them in the door as customers.

pros: Working with students and sharing knowledge.
cons: The University now expects twice the work for half the pay. Many great employees left last quarter. Mostly due to unethical coverups by administration. With our department losing so many people, it leaves those left overwhelmed and overworked. Can’t wait to retire.

review_title: The last few years Sullivan University is not the place I came to work for awhile back
pros: Good hours, and some good people, unfortunately all the good people are not in upper management. Faculty is awsome, especially NCHS.
cons: Unreal expectations, backstabbing and a me, me, me atmosphere. The students are a dollar sign anymore. Its education, the kids will be in debt forever with the cost of education here.

pros: Positive work environment, making a difference. Everyone really cares about the students and their success. Senior leadership is ethical and cares about overall success.
cons: Too many Saturday's required. This is a great university but needs to be not for profit status so people will stop judging.

review_title: Great opportunity to teach and share.
pros:
Well equipped classrooms.
Helpful faculty and staff. 
Enjoyed teaching students from all walks of life for 3 years.
cons: Online classes appeared .to be reserved for instructors located at Louisville campus only. Minor consideration given to non-Louisville based faculty.

review_title: Enjoy being belittled? This is the place for you!
pros: Free master's degree. That's honestly the only pro I can come up with, as every other day was filled with dread.
cons: Being degraded for no reason. Zero professional development. No work/life balance. Asking for help but being told that you're an idiot for even asking.

review_title: Ultimately a lost opportunity for employee and employer
pros: The company offered competitive pay and decent benefits after six months of employment.
cons: Poor training for role responsibilities, was trained by other departments in an effort to understand my job.  It did not give the proper understanding.  Not enough constructive feedback in order to actively work on poor work performance.

job_title: Financial Planning Coordinator in Louisville, KY
pros: the co workers were nice.
cons: management, the financial aid department wasn't treated as good as other departments. Worked a ton of Saturdays. Lied to during interview. high turnover rate.

pros:
Strong & supportive leadership
Promote continued education & professional development for faculty & staff.
cons:
Low pay & high health insurance costs.
Can be difficult to advance

pros: Laid back work environment, friendly staff and management, free tuition after employed for one year, variety of job opportunities/growth
cons: lower pay than some comparable companies/positions, lack of communication between some departments, some work accomplishments go unrecognized

review_title: Would never recommend this company to anyone
pros: They tend to look the other way a lot of times for certain employees mistakes.
cons: Terrible work environment. Only people in certain cliches advance. High school type mentality.

pros: I could not find any pros
cons: work conditions, overzealous managment, No 401K, work day and night,  faculty offices are classrooms, work as all in one teacher, pay top medical insurance premuim and get $14000 deductables insurance, thus they do not want you to see doctors.

review_title: Sullivan University exemplifies the best practices in career education... a pleasure to work with and for.
job_title: Senior Associate Director in Louisville, KY
pros: Professional, opportunity, collaboration and integrity
cons: High standards, expectations and accountability

pros: Awesome salary, good people, great educational benefits
cons: Long hours at times, admissions is tough sometimes

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Knox, KY
pros: Small family owned company, relationships!  Education benefit is huge!
cons: Small family owned company is VERY conservative, often resistant to logical change.

pros: Rated as one of best companies to work for in Kentucky by employers
cons: Privately owned, big turnover on entry level

pros: Excellent learning environment, Great lead Instructors
cons: Need is based upon class enrollment which can fluctuate widely

pros: Great people to work with, opportunities to grow within company, employee training's, positive environment
cons: Expensive medical plan and lots of calling

pros: Academic freedom and coworker camaraderie!
cons: PPO group healthcare premium costs are 'a choker' v. Medicare

pros: Faculty are collaborative and team players.
cons: Salary and health benefits could be better.

pros: It was a decent place to work.
cons: A bit too pushy sales wise on potential students.

pros: The culture of the university is warm and welcoming.
cons: There is no benefits for part-time professors.

pros: Great people to work with and very flexible!
cons: Pay not very good and no raises.

pros: Tuition reimbursement after some employment time
cons: Obscenely low pay, minimal health insurance benefits at a pricey cost to employee
